  <!-- ======== START OF CLASS DATA ======== --> 
  <h2> <font size="-1"> javax.mail.internet</font> <br> Class InternetAddress</h2> 
  <pre>
java.lang.Object
  <img SRC="../../../resources/inherit.gif" ALT="extended by "><a href="../../../javax/mail/Address.html" title="class in javax.mail">javax.mail.Address</a>
      <img SRC="../../../resources/inherit.gif" ALT="extended by "><b>javax.mail.internet.InternetAddress</b>
</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dt>
    <b>All Implemented Interfaces:</b> 
   </dt>
   <dd>
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <dl> 
   <dt>
    <pre>public class <b>InternetAddress</b>
     <dt>
      extends 
      <a href="../../../javax/mail/Address.html" title="class in javax.mail">Address</a>
     </dt>
     <dt>
      implements java.lang.Cloneable
     </dt></pre>
   </dt>
  </dl>  
  <p> This class represents an Internet email address using the syntax of <a href="http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc822.txt">RFC822</a>. Typical address syntax is of the form "user@host.domain" or "Personal Name &lt;user@host.domain&gt;". </p>
  <p> </p>
  <p> </p>
  <dl> 
   <dt>
    <b>Author:</b>
   </dt> 
   <dd>
    Bill Shannon, John Mani
   </dd> 
   <dt>
    <b>See Also:</b>
   </dt>
   <dd>
    <a href="../../../serialized-form.html#javax.mail.internet.InternetAddress">Serialized Form</a>
   </dd>
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <p> 
   <!-- =========== FIELD SUMMARY =========== --> <a name="field_summary">
    <!-- --></a> </p>
  <table border="1" width="100%" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" summary=""> 
   <tbody>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCCCFF" class="TableHeadingColor"> 
     <th align="left" colspan="2"><font size="+2"> <b>Field Summary</b></font></th> 
    </tr> 
    <tr bgcolor="white" class="TableRowColor"> 
     <td align="right" valign="top" width="1%"><font size="-1"> <code>protected &nbsp;java.lang.String</code></font></td> 
     <td><code><b><a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/InternetAddress.html#address">address</a></b></code> <br> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr bgcolor="white" class="TableRowColor">

    </tr>

    </tr> 
   </tbody>
  </table> &nbsp;

  <a name="address">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> address</h3> 
  <pre>
protected java.lang.String <b>address</b></pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dl> 
   </dl> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="personal">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> personal</h3> 
  <pre>
protected java.lang.String <b>personal</b></pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    The personal name. 
    <p> </p>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd>
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="encodedPersonal">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> encodedPersonal</h3> 
  <pre>
protected java.lang.String <b>encodedPersonal</b></pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    The RFC 2047 encoded version of the personal name. 
    <p> This field and the <code>personal</code> field track each other, so if a subclass sets one of these fields directly, it should set the other to <code>null</code>, so that it is suitably recomputed. </p>
    <p> </p>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd>
  </dl> 
  <!-- ========= CONSTRUCTOR DETAIL ======== --> 
  <a name="constructor_detail">
   <!-- --></a> 
  <table border="1" width="100%" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" summary=""> 
   <tbody>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCCCFF" class="TableHeadingColor"> 
     <th align="left" colspan="1"><font size="+2"> <b>Constructor Detail</b></font></th> 
    </tr> 
   </tbody>
  </table> 
  <a name="InternetAddress()">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> InternetAddress</h3> 
  <pre>
public <b>InternetAddress</b>()</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Default constructor. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="InternetAddress(java.lang.String)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> InternetAddress</h3> 
  <pre>
public <b>InternetAddress</b>(java.lang.String&nbsp;address)
                throws <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/AddressException.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">AddressException</a></pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Constructor. 
    <p> Parse the given string and create an InternetAddress. See the <code>parse</code> method for details of the parsing. The address is parsed using "strict" parsing. This constructor does <b>not</b> perform the additional syntax checks that the <code>InternetAddress(String address, boolean strict)</code> constructor does when <code>strict</code> is <code>true</code>. This constructor is equivalent to <code>InternetAddress(address, false)</code>. </p>
    <p> </p>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>address</code> - the address in RFC822 format 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>AddressException</code> - if the parse failed
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd>
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="InternetAddress(java.lang.String, boolean)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> InternetAddress</h3> 
  <pre>
public <b>InternetAddress</b>(java.lang.String&nbsp;address,
                       boolean&nbsp;strict)
                throws <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/AddressException.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">AddressException</a></pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Parse the given string and create an InternetAddress. If 
    <code>strict</code> is false, the detailed syntax of the address isn't checked. 
    <p> </p>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>address</code> - the address in RFC822 format
     </dd>
     <dd>
      <code>strict</code> - enforce RFC822 syntax 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>AddressException</code> - if the parse failed
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Since:</b>
     </dt> 
     <dd>
      JavaMail 1.3
     </dd> 
    </dl> 
   </dd>
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="InternetAddress(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> InternetAddress</h3> 
  <pre>
public <b>InternetAddress</b>(java.lang.String&nbsp;address,
                       java.lang.String&nbsp;personal)
                throws java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Construct an InternetAddress given the address and personal name. The address is assumed to be a syntactically valid RFC822 address. 
    <p> </p>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>address</code> - the address in RFC822 format
     </dd>
     <dd>
      <code>personal</code> - the personal name 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException</code>
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd>
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="InternetAddress(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.lang.String)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> InternetAddress</h3> 
  <pre>
public <b>InternetAddress</b>(java.lang.String&nbsp;address,
                       java.lang.String&nbsp;personal,
                       java.lang.String&nbsp;charset)
                throws java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Construct an InternetAddress given the address and personal name. The address is assumed to be a syntactically valid RFC822 address. 
    <p> </p>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>address</code> - the address in RFC822 format
     </dd>
     <dd>
      <code>personal</code> - the personal name
     </dd>
     <dd>
      <code>charset</code> - the MIME charset for the name 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException</code>
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd>
  </dl> 
  <!-- ============ METHOD DETAIL ========== --> 
  <a name="method_detail">
   <!-- --></a> 
  <table border="1" width="100%" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" summary=""> 
   <tbody>
    <tr bgcolor="#CCCCFF" class="TableHeadingColor"> 
     <th align="left" colspan="1"><font size="+2"> <b>Method Detail</b></font></th> 
    </tr> 
   </tbody>
  </table> 
  <a name="clone()">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> clone</h3> 
  <pre>
public java.lang.Object <b>clone</b>()</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Return a copy of this InternetAddress object. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Overrides:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>clone</code> in class 
      <code>java.lang.Object</code>
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Since:</b>
     </dt> 
     <dd>
      JavaMail 1.2
     </dd> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="getType()">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> getType</h3> 
  <pre>
public java.lang.String <b>getType</b>()</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Return the type of this address. The type of an InternetAddress is "rfc822". 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Specified by:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code><a href="../../../javax/mail/Address.html#getType()">getType</a></code> in class 
      <code><a href="../../../javax/mail/Address.html" title="class in javax.mail">Address</a></code>
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      address type
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>See Also:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/InternetAddress.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet"><code>InternetAddress</code></a>
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="setAddress(java.lang.String)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> setAddress</h3> 
  <pre>
public void <b>setAddress</b>(java.lang.String&nbsp;address)</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Set the email address. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>address</code> - email address
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="setPersonal(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> setPersonal</h3> 
  <pre>
public void <b>setPersonal</b>(java.lang.String&nbsp;name,
                        java.lang.String&nbsp;charset)
                 throws java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Set the personal name. If the name contains non US-ASCII characters, then the name will be encoded using the specified charset as per RFC 2047. If the name contains only US-ASCII characters, no encoding is done and the name is used as is. 
    <p> </p>
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>name</code> - personal name
     </dd>
     <dd>
      <code>charset</code> - MIME charset to be used to encode the name as per RFC 2047 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException</code> - if the charset encoding fails.
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>See Also:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/InternetAddress.html#setPersonal(java.lang.String)"><code>setPersonal(String)</code></a>
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="setPersonal(java.lang.String)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> setPersonal</h3> 
  <pre>
public void <b>setPersonal</b>(java.lang.String&nbsp;name)
                 throws java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Set the personal name. If the name contains non US-ASCII characters, then the name will be encoded using the platform's default charset. If the name contains only US-ASCII characters, no encoding is done and the name is used as is. 
    <p> </p>
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>name</code> - personal name 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException</code> - if the charset encoding fails.
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>See Also:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/InternetAddress.html#setPersonal(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)"><code>setPersonal(String name, String charset)</code></a>
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="getAddress()">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> getAddress</h3> 
  <pre>
public java.lang.String <b>getAddress</b>()</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Get the email address. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      email address
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="getPersonal()">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> getPersonal</h3> 
  <pre>
public java.lang.String <b>getPersonal</b>()</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Get the personal name. If the name is encoded as per RFC 2047, it is decoded and converted into Unicode. If the decoding or conversion fails, the raw data is returned as is. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      personal name
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="toString()">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> toString</h3> 
  <pre>
public java.lang.String <b>toString</b>()</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Convert this address into a RFC 822 / RFC 2047 encoded address. The resulting string contains only US-ASCII characters, and hence is mail-safe. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Specified by:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code><a href="../../../javax/mail/Address.html#toString()">toString</a></code> in class 
      <code><a href="../../../javax/mail/Address.html" title="class in javax.mail">Address</a></code>
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      possibly encoded address string
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="toUnicodeString()">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> toUnicodeString</h3> 
  <pre>
public java.lang.String <b>toUnicodeString</b>()</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Returns a properly formatted address (RFC 822 syntax) of Unicode characters. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      Unicode address string
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Since:</b>
     </dt> 
     <dd>
      JavaMail 1.2
     </dd> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr>

   <!-- --></a>

public boolean <b>equals</b>(java.lang.Object&nbsp;a)</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    The equality operator. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Specified by:</b>
     </dt>

     </dd>

public int <b>hashCode</b>()</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Compute a hash code for the address. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Overrides:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>

  <hr> 
  <a name="toString(javax.mail.Address[])">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> toString</h3> 
  <pre>
public static java.lang.String <b>toString</b>(<a href="../../../javax/mail/Address.html" title="class in javax.mail">Address</a>[]&nbsp;addresses)</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Convert the given array of InternetAddress objects into a comma separated sequence of address strings. The resulting string contains only US-ASCII characters, and hence is mail-safe. 
    <p> </p>
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>addresses</code> - array of InternetAddress objects 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      comma separated string of addresses 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>ClassCastException,</code> - if any address object in the given array is not an InternetAddress object. Note that this is a RuntimeException.
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="toString(javax.mail.Address[], int)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> toString</h3> 
  <pre>
public static java.lang.String <b>toString</b>(<a href="../../../javax/mail/Address.html" title="class in javax.mail">Address</a>[]&nbsp;addresses,
                                        int&nbsp;used)</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Convert the given array of InternetAddress objects into a comma separated sequence of address strings. The resulting string contains only US-ASCII characters, and hence is mail-safe. 
    <p> The 'used' parameter specifies the number of character positions already taken up in the field into which the resulting address sequence string is to be inserted. It is used to determine the line-break positions in the resulting address sequence string. </p>
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>addresses</code> - array of InternetAddress objects
     </dd>
     <dd>
      <code>used</code> - number of character positions already used, in the field into which the address string is to be inserted. 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      comma separated string of addresses 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>ClassCastException,</code> - if any address object in the given array is not an InternetAddress object. Note that this is a RuntimeException.
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="getLocalAddress(javax.mail.Session)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> getLocalAddress</h3> 
  <pre>
public static <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/InternetAddress.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">InternetAddress</a> <b>getLocalAddress</b>(<a href="../../../javax/mail/Session.html" title="class in javax.mail">Session</a>&nbsp;session)</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Return an InternetAddress object representing the current user. The entire email address may be specified in the "mail.from" property. If not set, the "mail.user" and "mail.host" properties are tried. If those are not set, the "user.name" property and 
    <code>InetAddress.getLocalHost</code> method are tried. Security exceptions that may occur while accessing this information are ignored. If it is not possible to determine an email address, null is returned. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>session</code> - Session object used for property lookup 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      current user's email address
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="parse(java.lang.String)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> parse</h3> 
  <pre>
public static <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/InternetAddress.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">InternetAddress</a>[] <b>parse</b>(java.lang.String&nbsp;addresslist)
                               throws <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/AddressException.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">AddressException</a></pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Parse the given comma separated sequence of addresses into InternetAddress objects. Addresses must follow RFC822 syntax. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>addresslist</code> - comma separated address strings 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      array of InternetAddress objects 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>AddressException</code> - if the parse failed
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="parse(java.lang.String, boolean)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> parse</h3> 
  <pre>
public static <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/InternetAddress.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">InternetAddress</a>[] <b>parse</b>(java.lang.String&nbsp;addresslist,
                                      boolean&nbsp;strict)
                               throws <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/AddressException.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">AddressException</a></pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Parse the given sequence of addresses into InternetAddress objects. If 
    <code>strict</code> is false, simple email addresses separated by spaces are also allowed. If 
    <code>strict</code> is true, many (but not all) of the RFC822 syntax rules are enforced. In particular, even if 
    <code>strict</code> is true, addresses composed of simple names (with no "@domain" part) are allowed. Such "illegal" addresses are not uncommon in real messages. 
    <p> Non-strict parsing is typically used when parsing a list of mail addresses entered by a human. Strict parsing is typically used when parsing address headers in mail messages. </p>
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>addresslist</code> - comma separated address strings
     </dd>
     <dd>
      <code>strict</code> - enforce RFC822 syntax 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      array of InternetAddress objects 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>AddressException</code> - if the parse failed
     </dd>
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="parseHeader(java.lang.String, boolean)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> parseHeader</h3> 
  <pre>
public static <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/InternetAddress.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">InternetAddress</a>[] <b>parseHeader</b>(java.lang.String&nbsp;addresslist,
                                            boolean&nbsp;strict)
                                     throws <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/AddressException.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">AddressException</a></pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Parse the given sequence of addresses into InternetAddress objects. If 
    <code>strict</code> is false, the full syntax rules for individual addresses are not enforced. If 
    <code>strict</code> is true, many (but not all) of the RFC822 syntax rules are enforced. 
    <p> To better support the range of "invalid" addresses seen in real messages, this method enforces fewer syntax rules than the <code>parse</code> method when the strict flag is false and enforces more rules when the strict flag is true. If the strict flag is false and the parse is successful in separating out an email address or addresses, the syntax of the addresses themselves is not checked. </p>
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Parameters:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>addresslist</code> - comma separated address strings
     </dd>
     <dd>
      <code>strict</code> - enforce RFC822 syntax 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      array of InternetAddress objects 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>AddressException</code> - if the parse failed
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Since:</b>
     </dt> 
     <dd>
      JavaMail 1.3
     </dd> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="validate()">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> validate</h3> 
  <pre>
public void <b>validate</b>()
              throws <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/AddressException.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">AddressException</a></pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Validate that this address conforms to the syntax rules of RFC 822. The current implementation checks many, but not all, syntax rules. Note that even though the syntax of the address may be correct, there's no guarantee that a mailbox of that name exists. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>AddressException</code> - if the address isn't valid.
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Since:</b>
     </dt> 
     <dd>
      JavaMail 1.3
     </dd> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="isGroup()">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> isGroup</h3> 
  <pre>
public boolean <b>isGroup</b>()</pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Indicates whether this address is an RFC 822 group address. Note that a group address is different than the mailing list addresses supported by most mail servers. Group addresses are rarely used; see RFC 822 for details. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      true if this address represents a group
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Since:</b>
     </dt> 
     <dd>
      JavaMail 1.3
     </dd> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <hr> 
  <a name="getGroup(boolean)">
   <!-- --></a>
  <h3> getGroup</h3> 
  <pre>
public <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/InternetAddress.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">InternetAddress</a>[] <b>getGroup</b>(boolean&nbsp;strict)
                           throws <a href="../../../javax/mail/internet/AddressException.html" title="class in javax.mail.internet">AddressException</a></pre> 
  <dl> 
   <dd>
    Return the members of a group address. A group may have zero, one, or more members. If this address is not a group, null is returned. The 
    <code>strict</code> parameter controls whether the group list is parsed using strict RFC 822 rules or not. The parsing is done using the 
    <code>parseHeader</code> method. 
    <p> </p>
   </dd>
   <dd>
    <dl> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
   <dd>
    <dl> 
     <dt>
      <b>Returns:</b>
     </dt>
     <dd>
      array of InternetAddress objects, or null 
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Throws:</b> 
     </dt>
     <dd>
      <code>AddressException</code> - if the group list can't be parsed
     </dd>
     <dt>
      <b>Since:</b>
     </dt> 
     <dd>
      JavaMail 1.3
     </dd> 
    </dl> 
   </dd> 
  </dl> 
  <!-- ========= END OF CLASS DATA ========= -->
